posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
So we just ended our competition at Lakeview 1 in FIM.

If you watch the last 4 seconds of the match, you can see our robot slowly go out and then struggle to come back into the community.

We are running SDS MK4i with falcons.  When we inspected the drive system right after the match, the back right motor was too hot to touch.  The back left motor was warm and the two front motors were room temp.

We finally got a chance to investigate today back in the shop.  And it turns out that the motor in question, the back right, was running backwards of all of the other pods.  We did not deploy any new code all day and you can see that our bot was running completely fine for the most part through out this match and the previous few matches.

We replaced that motor since it was also making an abnormal noise.  We did not change code and the back right wheel is now running in the correct direction.

How does that happen?  The motors are not brand new.   Is it possible that the talon FX got fried and reversed it’s polarity?  Has this happened to anyone else?

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: But it continue to run that motor in reverse this morning after multiple robot reboots and always only running the same deployed code in the RIO.  The init should have done its job after the reboot.

posts.name: RyanShoff
posts.cooked: You may have saved settings in the controller and someone reset the settings.  Not sure how to explain that happening mid match.

posts.name: Jeffrey Lewis
posts.cooked: We had this issue last year with our climber. Had one Falcon on each side of our robot each going through its own gearbox to drive each side of our climber, which was linked in the middle. While testing, it’d randomly start twisting itself. We were getting on the programmer about it, but he could never figure out what was going on. It would just randomly change directions. Finally ended up swapping the motor and never had the issue again. I don’t have a video showing the moment it changed, but I have videos from back-to back tests where they worked fine and then when one motor had changed directions the second time. These were less than a minute apart.

posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked:
We had the same issue! Had to swap out a Falcon between matches. Same SDS as you.

Just one motor, a drive motor to be exact, and it was extremely hot to the touch after.

Under no load, the motor would spin in reverse of the command given and then when we reversed the direction, the motor would stall.

Swapped for another Falcon, all is good. Tested that potentially bad Falcon on a test bed and it ran fine in both direction.

No idea why, but at least you know you were not alone in this mystery.

posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked: @jtrv yet another failure point of falcons?

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
@sthump @burde1jb From a software/firmware perspective this shouldn’t be possible unless there’s a call in your robot program inverting the direction that you’re not expecting.

From a hardware perspective we should be able to confirm or rule out a hardware or lower-level issue with some diagnostic info. Could each of you please reach out to us with the results of the following steps as soon as you have time?

You don’t need your robot code for this, just the temporary diagnostic server is sufficient.

Factory default the Talon FX controller using the config tab of Phoenix Tuner.

Factory default the Talon FX controller using the config tab of Phoenix Tuner.

Use Phoenix Tuner to run the Falcon at 100% forward percent output (free-speed, unloaded).  Take a self-test snapshot.

Use Phoenix Tuner to run the Falcon at 100% forward percent output (free-speed, unloaded).  Take a self-test snapshot.

Repeat # 2 but in the reverse direction.

Repeat # 2 but in the reverse direction.

Send us both snapshots (along with a brief statement to give context to the email) to support@ctr-electronics.com .

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Will get that done on Wednesday.

posts.name: Jacob Stone
posts.cooked: We had the same issue and it was a bad falcon
What was the problem with the Falcon? Did you send it in for diagnosis or did you open it up?

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked: Is it possible that you tripped a 40A breaker?  That could power cycle the Falcon and possibly loose settings you changed in your code (such as inversion state).

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
It is possible all of that happened.  But

code init to clockwise rotation which I think is what falcons do by default.

code init to clockwise rotation which I think is what falcons do by default.

the reverse polarity persists after the robot was power cycled.

the reverse polarity persists after the robot was power cycled.

Problem lies inside the falcon.

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
Orion.DeYoe:

That could power cycle the Falcon and possibly loose settings you changed in your code (such as inversion state).

I understand the thinking there, but from a firmware perspective that’s not possible.  When you set the invert for a CTR Motor Controller in code it’s a behind-the-scenes config that’s automatically saved to flash.  So it’s persistent across power cycles.

This is why the self-test I mentioned above are important, so we can dig into exactly what’s going on.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
